headline.main: NEWS FROM EUROPE.; Threatening State of European Politics. THE MOROCCO WAR. The Great Storms in England. Arrival of the Hungarian and the Asia.

docs.lead_paragraph: The steamship Hungarian, Capt. Jones, with sixty-four passengers, left Liverpool at 12:10 P. M. of the 2d inst., and arrived here this (Sunday) morning at 10:30, it being eleven days passage, including a detention of six hours at Newfoundland in rescuing and landing the crew of the shipwrecked vessel as before reported.

docs.snippet: CITY MORALITY.-Dr. BOYD, Health Officer, reports 83 deaths for the week ending Saturday last, classified as follows : Men, 15 ; women, 18 ; boys, 26 ; girls, 24. Adults, 33 ; children, 50. Males, 41 ; Females, 42. Colored persons, 1. Fifty-two were...
docs.lead_paragraph: CITY MORALITY.-Dr. BOYD, Health Officer, reports 83 deaths for the week ending Saturday last, classified as follows : Men, 15 ; women, 18 ; boys, 26 ; girls, 24. Adults, 33 ; children, 50. Males, 41 ; Females, 42. Colored persons, 1. Fifty-two were under 20, and 7 were over 50 years of age. Sixty-one were natives of the United States.

docs.snippet: The ship Emily arrived at this port yesterday in charge of Lieut. H. K. STEVENS and a prize crew from the United States sloop-of-war Portsmouth, of the African squadron. She was seized on the 22d of September by Capt. CALHOUN, of the Portsmouth,...

headline.main: THE SLAVE-TRADE.; HER ARRIVAL AT THIS PORT. A New-York Bark Seized on the Coast of Africa.

docs.lead_paragraph: The ship Emily arrived at this port yesterday in charge of Lieut. H. K. STEVENS and a prize crew from the United States sloop-of-war Portsmouth, of the African squadron. She was seized on the 22d of September by Capt. CALHOUN, of the Portsmouth, under circumstances which strongly indicated that she was about to engage in the Slave-trade.

docs.snippet: SEOOND DAY'S PROCEEDINGS. The countrymen of SCHILLER were even more enthusiastic in the City yesterday, than on the previous day, and business among them seemed to be generally laid aside. The first public proceedings in the poet's honor commenced at...

headline.main: THE SCHILLER CENTENARY.; Orations at the Cooper Institute, by W. C. Bryant, Esq., Hon. Judge Daly, Drs. Schramm, Wicsner, &c.--Jubilee at the Academy of Music.

docs.lead_paragraph: SEOOND DAY'S PROCEEDINGS. The countrymen of SCHILLER were even more enthusiastic in the City yesterday, than on the previous day, and business among them seemed to be generally laid aside. The first public proceedings in the poet's honor commenced at 1 P. M, in the great hall of the Cooper Institute, which was comfortably filled-not to overflowing-with a most respectable and intelligent audience, among whom there was a fair sprinkling of Americans.

docs.snippet: At last the Commander of the Military Department of New Mexico has taken measures to punish the Apaches. An expedition is now in the field against them. Orders have been sent to Fort Fillmore to the commanding officer for Licuts. McNEIL, LORD and...

headline.main: FROM ARIZONA.; Indian Troubles--Excitement and Apprehensions--Expedition Against the Apaches..

docs.lead_paragraph: At last the Commander of the Military Department of New Mexico has taken measures to punish the Apaches. An expedition is now in the field against them. Orders have been sent to Fort Fillmore to the commanding officer for Licuts. McNEIL, LORD and HowLAND, with 140 men of the dragoons and rifles, to report themselves to Lieut.Col. REEVE, at Fort Buchanan.

docs.snippet: Dr. CHEEVER, as many of our readers are aware, is one of the most able and self-sacrificing friends of the slave in the New World. It was scarcely possible for a minister of the Gospel in the Empire City to pursue a course so straightforward, and to...

headline.main: THE QUESTION OF SLAVERY.; REMARKABLE LETTER FROM REV. GEO. B. CHEEVER TO REV. C. H. SPURGEON. Appeal of American Abolitionists for British Pecuniary Aid.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. CHEEVER, as many of our readers are aware, is one of the most able and self-sacrificing friends of the slave in the New World. It was scarcely possible for a minister of the Gospel in the Empire City to pursue a course so straightforward, and to make war with so strong a hand against the slaveholder, without exposing himself on every side to hostile influences.

docs.snippet: Rev. John L. Girardeau, of Charleston, publishes a card in relation to his connection with the religious instruction of the colored people, and is very solicitous to be understood by his Southern friends. He recognizes the divine character of the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Rev. John L. Girardeau, of Charleston, publishes a card in relation to his connection with the religious instruction of the colored people, and is very solicitous to be understood by his Southern friends. He recognizes the divine character of the relation of master and slave, and repels certain charges which have recently been made against him by the following declaration:
